job_title: ICC and Then Therapeutic Mentor in Beverly, MA
pros:
-Getting to work with a target population of youth that need help and advocacy.  
-Those without Manager positions are very cordial and easy to work with and appear to take pride in their work.
cons:
-Company couldn't care less about their target population
-Company does everything they can to "low-ball" the employees (just look at the turnover)
-3 years with the company and if you asked me if I knew the name of the company president or even anyone above my supervisor, I wouldn't be able to tell you
-No room for growth
-New standards set forth by insurance companies create burden for workers and there appears to be no hesitance on behalf of management or else to rectify these burdens or to advocate for employees as to why some of these standards are unreasonable
-If you need insurance, standard procedure for most companies may be to deduct a couple of dollars per hour and to deduct money from each paycheck.  That is fine but when this company realizes you need insurance and options are limited, they cut your pay by $7 per hour (trust me that's a lot) in addition to deducting $120+ out of each bi-weekly paycheck.  That's for an individual plan.

review_title: Floor staff need better pay and support
pros: Great coworkers and clients, good benefits, and an opportunity to make a difference in the lives of clients. Opportunities for additional training.
cons: Floor staff are grossly underpaid for the work they do, staff is great but stretched too thin due to constantly being understaffed. Upper management is often critical and unappreciative of floor staff, having high expectations of underpaid, overworked, and under-trained employees.

pros:

Micromanaged-people are scrutinized for socializing in between client sessions
Clinicians are overbooked with little regard for emotionally draining work
Asked to do more and more without compensation

some clinicians speak disrespectfully about one another and clients
Impossible to take time off without it being held against you with productivity
Has been described as a "sinking ship"

Many feel stuck and uninspired by what they do and not because they're not talented

review_title: I would never recommend this workplace
pros: The staff in this office were great, they were always willing to lend a helping hand. The clinician I worked with made sure I always had what I needed and supported me to move forward in my career.
cons: HA, where do I start. Well for this job title you must posses a bachelors level degree yet they will only pay you under $15.00 an hour. For working 40 hours salary paid (based on productivity hours), expect to be working 50 hours a week to make that productivity, due to not being able to bill driving time, or time spent preparing for your clients. If you do not meet productivity you will be placed on negative hours and be expected to make up those hours or risk being bumped down to 30 hours, or fired. After working with this company 8 months I found a new job and gave my proper 2 week notice, now I am in the process of fighting for money they owe me (ETO, Millage, and my last day of pay). DO NOT WORK FOR LAHEY HEALTH BEHAVIORAL SERVICES!!!

pros: Good people to work with.
cons: Pay, pay, pay, pay, pay.

job_title: Case Manager in Corpus Christi, TX
pros:
401k
Health Insurance 
Gym membership
Paid Holidays
cons: No time for training in a fast paced environment. You either sink or swim and get blamed for not doing your work accurately. However they lack the basic essentials to get new employees trained. Not to mention as soon as they hired our CEO the firm has slowly gone downhill. In the past years i never had to rely on a raise that was valued as cents. To top it off others were able to get a second chance to get additional monies considered for their pay increase, not fair. Around here its not what you know its who you know... Instead of a huge lavish Christmas party why not give us more money for our bonus instead of getting a small check thats taxed atleast half... Also the fact that they give you the run around when its something you need but when its what they need they expect you to bend forward and backwards.

job_title: Behavioral Health Clinician in Gloucester, MA
pros: Good health insurance and a lot of vacation time through accrued PTO (you can combine sick and vacation to use however you want).
cons: You have to be full time to take advantage of getting additional pay for extra hours worked. Clinicians are pushed to see at least 24 clients per week if full time or there are repercussions. The expectation is to schedule between 28 and 30 as well as manage the completion of all notes (a detailed note that requires erroneous information) as well as attend staff meetings and med provider meetings. Full time clinicians are paid poorly (45-50,000) and work approximately 50-60hrs per week. Burnout happens quickly and thier retention of employees is almost non existent.

review_title: New management should read the handbook
pros: Great staff, families are wonderful for the most part.   Ability to work from home, very flexible.  Supervision is consistent and helpful.
cons: New management.  Have favorites so some workers are not held to the program requirements.  Said special employees bring what appear to be gifts to the supervisor allowing the special treatment.  Looks like bribery.  Some employees get written up for things the special employees get away with.

pros: Capacity to work independently due to lack of consistent leadership and endless opportunities to try on new roles due to every changing structure.  Management appeared respectful of days off and family obligations.
cons: Leadership changes frequently at all levels which creates a lacking of relationship building and consistent support. Divisions restructure on what seemed like a rolling basis so although each division is connected to a large organization which would lend to opportunity, it is hard to even know who is it what role and in what division in order to actually access the continuum of services and knowledge.

review_title: For 22 years, I was the Director of Mobile Home Visiting which functioned as a crisis outreach/assessment service,
job_title: Ex-Supervisor Pf Blended Case Management in Philadelphia, PA
pros: For most of these 22 years, had great support from Administration, staff and County Office. Then, the program was defunded and eliminated. I was kept on for 2 years in the position of Case management supervisor, but was terminated at-will from that postion by a new (to me) supervisor.
cons: The utlimate insult: Terminated for cause, essnetially because I accidentally emailed the monthly report twice to the Executive Director.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Beverly, MA
pros: There is never a shortage of clients.
cons: Incompetent and condescending middle managers and poor supervision. Poor work/life balance. Every full-time clinician had to work overtime to attempt to meet continuously rising productivity hours. Employees were given a pay cut and execs received 8% raises in the same year. The result is that the clients aren't helped in the long run. What most managers seem to ask of the counselors is to enable their clients.

pros: Coworkers are almost exclusively wonderful and competent. They are very supportive of each other and of the people being served. Too many volunteer their time since they are working over 40 hours a week.
cons: Management is not even reasonably transparent. Decisions are frequently made affecting clients and staff without regard for either. Revenue generation is the priority at lahey, even over client care.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Lowell, MA
pros: Excellent clinical experience is garnered in this environment. One can work in emergency rooms LGH/Saints; assessments are completed in multiple types of environments: homes, schools, offices, police departments, etc.
cons: Specific employees are targeted.  Harmful unsubstantiated accusations written in your employee file which may require legal intervention to protest; the therapists here need support from their company to learn self-care, and should be encouraged to take days off when necessary.  Furthermore, if you are attempting to become a LMHC, be sure you review your post-graduate licensure hours on a monthly basis, so you will not experience any surprises with LHBS proposing lower hours than you believe you had attained.

pros: Flexible scheduling (if YOU can remain firm in your wants/needs), great clients who seem to appreciate the help and staff and wonderful immediate colleagues.
cons: Poor management, upper management not being involved with lower staffing concerns or safety, all floor staff seem to be "on call" and are contacted often when not scheduled or present without prior warning of "on call" status, also not paid for on-call (only admin). serious lack of direct supervision.

job_title: Consulting Solutions Manager in Danvers, MA
pros: I love working with clients and helping them achieve their goals
cons: The pay is disgustingly low, there are no licensed therapists, the whole place is very disorganized, management does not have our backs, and we are very under appreciated. I can’t even get a functional office chair

pros: Very rewarding, worked side by side with some amazing people
cons: The upper management brushes everything under the rug and makes it very clear that floor staff are dispensable. Kevin Norton and HR are really the only ones to go to if you need help.

pros: They offer pleanty of over time. They offer set hours and scheduling. Good benifet packages. Pleanty of opportunities to advance if you so chose.
cons: The staff are often as mentally compromised as the clients. They pay on the low end of human service spectrum. Management is careless and are not very invested in the staff or the clients.

pros: Some genuinely friendly, hard-working, compassionate Therapists and Admin staff; PCs in every office; nice work environment; interesting, challenging Clients.
cons:
Too much intake and other paperwork. 

Central Scheduling: too rigid, not flexible enough; too much power/interaction with Clients, changing Therapy appointments without informing the Therapists, often leaving the Therapists out of touch as to their Clients schedules; too much time wasted answering Central Scheduling emails and phone calls. 

Office room scheduling: I worked in more than 6 different offices during my employment, frequently switching offices daily to see Clients. Some hours I didn't even have an office to work from!

pros: If you like substance abuse counseling this is the job!
cons: High client turnover rate and high employee turnover rate.

pros: Colleagues, patients, time-off flexibility, small incentives
cons: Low pay, little incentive for hard work, increasing work load, dilapidated building, limited support for staff, poorly trained managers

pros: Supportive co workers, clients are the best
cons: No supervisor/ program directors, clinical directors  for staff members no support from upper management. Inexperienced supervisors

pros:
Management at Boston Treatment Center is amazing. The Clinical Director, the Direct-Care Supervisor, and the Program Director are amazing - you are lucky to have them. (This is not to be confused with Lahey Health Behavioral Services management in Danvers...they couldn't care less about clients or staff. It's all about the profit for them).

Some of the staff are so so nice and fun to work with. There are some people who are real team players and I enjoyed spending time with them. 

The health benefits are great - with low premiums for those who work at least 30 hours. They also offer benefits to part-time staff which is great. They will attempt to hire you as Per Diem (yet give you 40 hours) so they don't have to give you benefits though. 

Great PTO benefits.
cons:
Boston Treatment Center, a detox run by Lahey Health Behavioral Services, is a necessity for the community it serves, but it needs a lot of improvement.

Firstly, so many staff members are under-educated, unqualified, and uncaring - the nursing staff in particular. Clients are treated very poorly by nursing (not all nurses - there are 3 or 4 I can think of who are amazing). When clients are asking for help or are trying to speak to a nurse they are often completely ignored. The nurses will just be on their phone - they can clearly hear the client - and they just pretend they are not there. It can be like walking on eggshells for a client to try to talk to the nurses or ask them for something. Sometimes nurses will refuse to admit someone for no good reason too.

******** Again, as mentioned in the "Pros" section, THIS DOES NOT INCLUDE the Clinical Director, the Direct-Care Supervisor, and the Program Director - they are amazing. ********

I understand that Boston Treatment Center treats a difficult population, but you knew that when you started working there. If you can't handle SICK withdrawing clients being a bit irritated and rude, work somewhere else. Have some compassion for these people and don't stoop to their level. You are a clinician, they are a patient. You are not on the streets.

There are some staff members who would be much better suited as Correctional Officers at South Bay. YOU CANNOT SCREAM AT CLIENTS. I don't understand why some people have been allowed to work there for so long with the way they treat clients.

The pay is horrible. What kind of hospital organization pays its full-time staff so so low that they qualify for SNAP and WIC? It's terrible. For the amount of work that case managers have to do, the paychecks are insulting.

Also, the area is extremely dangerous and there is no security. Allegedly we have access to BPHC's security because they own the building, but I have never seen their presence in the building. Tewksbury detox has a security guard in the building and they are basically located in the woods, we should have one too. Staff members have asked Danvers multiple times for a security presence in the building. Clients can be unpredictable.

There is also little to no accountability when it comes to incompetent staff. Staff members are defended to a fault - when they should be fired for misconduct and subordination. So many staff also steal from each other. No respect. I think some staff also steal clients' cigarettes.

Don't even get me started on COVID protocols and responses. The email from the CEO talking about his cut in pay as a sacrifice for the company was pretty laughable. I can't even believe you sent that email to us. We're out here with no hazard pay making 30k a year and sitting across the desk (with no protective divider) from people who are at a high risk of having Covid-19. Your temporary pay cut doesn't impress us! Grocery stores are providing more protection to their employees than you (a medical facility) are.

pros: Most employees are great, supportive, professional co-workers
cons: pay, productivity demands, micromanaging, treating mental health therapy like someone is being seen for a medical problem
